title: Lauren Boebert
added: Boebert opposes [[socialism]].<ref name="GSPostInd12102019">{{cite news |last=Phippen |first=Thomas |date=December 10, 2019 |title=Rifle congressional candidate Lauren Boebert aims to be the conservative AOC |url=https://www.vaildaily.com/news/colorado/rifle-congressional-candidate-lauren-boebert-aims-to-be-the-conservative-aoc/ |work=Glenwood Springs Post Independent |location=[[Glenwood Springs, Colorado]] |publisher=Aspen Daily |access-date=August 20, 2020 |quote=“(Ocasio-Cortez) is putting on a progressive, socialist narrative to our people. I’m going to be the one who changes that conversation back to the Constitution, and what this country was founded on,” Boebert said in an interview.}}</ref><ref name="ColoPubRadio08242020"/>

title: Lauren Boebert
added: On January 13, she announced that [[Twitter]] had blocked her ability to post content until after January 20, 2021 because she had violated Twitter's rules.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Aedo|first=Zachary|date=2021-01-13|title=Rep. Lauren Boebert says Twitter account locked until Inauguration Day|url=https://krdo.com/news/2021/01/13/lauren-boeberts-twitter-account-locked-until-inauguration-day/|access-date=2021-01-13|website=KRDO|language=en-US}}</ref>

title: Lauren Boebert
deleted: On January 13, she announced that [[Twitter]] had blocked her ability to post content until after January 20, 2021 because she had violated Twitter's rules.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Aedo|first=Zachary|date=2021-01-13|title=Rep. Lauren Boebert says Twitter account locked until Inauguration Day|url=https://krdo.com/news/2021/01/13/lauren-boeberts-twitter-account-locked-until-inauguration-day/|access-date=2021-01-13|website=KRDO|language=en-US}}</ref> Within hours of the block, Twitter unblocked Boebert's account, citing that staff "took the incorrect enforcement action."<ref name="Canales">{{cite news |last1=Canales |first1=Katie |title=Twitter says it has reversed its 'incorrect' decision to lock Rep. Lauren Boebert's account |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-locks-boebert-account-pelosi-capitol-siege-2021-1 |access-date=14 January 2021 |work=Business Insider |date=13 January 2021}}</ref>

title: Lauren Boebert
deleted: In response to Congressman [[Sean Patrick Maloney]]′s (D-NY) allusion that some Congress members gave tours to rioters, Boebert described Maloney’s appearance on [[MSNBC]] as “lies.” Maloney noted that he never said her name in public, and added, “If you’re going to be a gun nut, you probably shouldn’t go off half cocked.” In response to reports that Boebert was live-streaming during the riot, Senator [[Brian Schatz]] (D-HI) said lawmakers had been instructed not to tell anyone, not even their families, their exact location.<ref name=gunnut>{{cite web |title=Lauren Boebert jumps gun, claims mentions of Congress member involved in Capitol riot refer to her |url=https://www.dailykos.com/stories/2021/1/15/2009438/-Lauren-Boebert-jumps-the-gun-assumes-mentions-of-a-congressman-involved-in-the-Capitol-riots-is-her?utm_source=rss&utm_medium=Sendible&utm_campaign=RSS&fbclid=IwAR31816Cod6pbsXelwVUaVMxiZHgiaoxxSYbJa-givpLtsR3DUnsovJeL8w |website=Daily Kos |access-date=January 18, 2021}}</ref> The House plans an investigation.
On January 12 Congresswoman refused to open her bag after an alarm went off on a metal detector set up by Capitol police.<ref name=gunnut/>

title: Lauren Boebert
deleted: Boebert has taken to Twitter recently to criticise David Hogg, a survivor of the Parkland school shooting [[https://www.denverpost.com/2021/01/28/lauren-boebert-david-hogg-democrats/]]

title: Lauren Boebert
added: It is rumored that her biological father is Professional Wrestler Stan “the man” Lane, who may also be Boeberts maternal uncle.

title: Lauren Boebert
deleted: It is rumored that her biological father is Professional Wrestler Stan “the man” Lane, who may also be Boeberts maternal uncle.

title: Lauren Boebert
deleted: In 2010, Boebert's neighbors called police because they believed her [[pit bull]]s were threatening their dogs. Boebert received a ticket for dog code violations.<ref name="dp 20200827">{{Cite news |last=Wingerter |first=Justin |date=August 27, 2020 |title=Congressional candidate Lauren Boebert has a history of minor arrests, court no-shows |language=en-US |work=[[The Denver Post]] |url=https://www.denverpost.com/2020/08/27/lauren-boebert-arrests-colorado-3rd-mitsch-bush/ |access-date=October 7, 2020 |archive-date=January 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116190758/https://www.denverpost.com/2020/08/27/lauren-boebert-arrests-colorado-3rd-mitsch-bush/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

In 2015, she was cited for [[misdemeanor]] [[disorderly conduct]] at a music festival for telling officers that their arrest of a couple of [[Legal drinking age|underage drinkers]] was [[Constitutionality|unconstitutional]] because the teenagers had not received ''[[Miranda warning|Miranda]]'' warnings.<ref name="FMillerColoNewsL08132020">Miller, Faith. [https://coloradonewsline.com/2020/08/13/report-lauren-boebert-warned-arresting-deputies-she-had-friends-at-fox-news/ Report: Lauren Boebert warned arresting deputies she had 'friends at Fox News'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210106145422/https://coloradonewsline.com/2020/08/13/report-lauren-boebert-warned-arresting-deputies-she-had-friends-at-fox-news/ |date=January 6, 2021 }}, ''Colorado Newsline'', August 13, 2020. Retrieved January 4, 2021.  "The Mesa County district attorney's office dismissed a class 1 petty offense charge against Boebert "in the interest of justice," writing that there was "no reasonable likelihood of conviction should (the) case go to trial.""</ref> As she was being handcuffed, according to deputies' reports, Boebert tried to twist away from police, saying that "she had friends at [[Fox News]]" and that the arrest would be "national news".<ref name="FMillerColoNewsL08132020"/> She twice failed to appear in court on the charge.<ref name="FMillerColoNewsL08132020"/> The petty offense was dismissed because the [[Mesa County, Colorado|Mesa County]] [[district attorney]]'s office believed a jury would not convict her.<ref name="FMillerColoNewsL08132020"/>

In 2016, Boebert was cited for operating an unsafe vehicle; she pleaded guilty.<ref name="dp 20200827" /><ref>Hulse, Carl (September 26, 2010) [https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/26/us/colorado-lauren-boebert-congress.html "In Colorado, Fiery Political Novice Aims for a Seat in the House."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201003221814/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/26/us/colorado-lauren-boebert-congress.html |date=October 3, 2020 }} New York Times. (Retrieved October 7, 2020.)</ref>

title: Lauren Boebert
added: ==== Role in storming of the Capitol ====

On January 5, the day before [[2021 storming of the United States Capitol|the storming of the United States Capitol]], Boebert tweeted, "Remember these next 48 hours. These are some of the most important days in American history."<ref>Silverii, Ian (January 17, 2021) [https://www.denverpost.com/2021/01/17/lauren-boebert-should-resign-expelled-capitol-attack/ "Silverii: U.S. Rep. Lauren Boebert should resign or be expelled."] Denver Post. (Retrieved January 17, 2021.)</ref> On January 6, in the hours before the Capitol was attacked, Boebert tweeted, "Today is [[United States Declaration of Independence|1776]]," a reference to the [[American Revolutionary War]].<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Edmondson|first1=Catie|last2=Broadwater|first2=Luke|date=January 12, 2021|title=Before Capitol Riot, Republican Lawmakers Fanned the Flames|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/11/us/politics/republicans-capitol-riot.html|access-date=January 12, 2021|issn=0362-4331|archive-date=January 13, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210113005821/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/11/us/politics/republicans-capitol-riot.html|url-status=live}}</ref> During the counting of the [[United States Electoral College|Electoral College]] votes, Boebert objected to counting [[Arizona]]'s votes in a speech to the [[Joint session of the United States Congress|joint session of Congress]]. She said, "The members who stand here today and accept the results of this concentrated, coordinated, partisan effort by Democrats—where every fraudulent vote canceled out the vote of an honest American—have sided with the extremist left."<ref>Wingerter, Justin (January 6, 2021) [https://www.denverpost.com/2021/01/06/congress-electoral-college-2020-biden-trump/ "Lauren Boebert and Joe Neguse debate Biden’s win on the House floor."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116190825/https://www.denverpost.com/2021/01/06/congress-electoral-college-2020-biden-trump/ |date=January 16, 2021 }} Denver Post. (Retrieved January 7, 2021.)</ref>

Democratic politicians in Colorado accused Boebert and her colleague [[Doug Lamborn]] of "helping incite violence" during the January 6 storming of the United States Capitol.<ref>Goodland, Marianne. [https://www.coloradopolitics.com/denver-gazette/elected-officials-and-others-demand-reps-boebert-lamborn-resign-over-wednesdays-washington-d-c-riot/article_3a2a74b8-5135-11eb-abdf-9f74bb3076d2.html State and local Democrats, others demand Reps. Boebert, Lamborn resign over Wednesday's Washington, D.C. riot] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116190743/https://www.coloradopolitics.com/denver-gazette/elected-officials-and-others-demand-reps-boebert-lamborn-resign-over-wednesdays-washington-d-c-riot/article_3a2a74b8-5135-11eb-abdf-9f74bb3076d2.html |date=January 16, 2021 }}, ''Colorado Politics'', January 7, 2021.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.9news.com/article/news/politics/officials-boebert-lamborn-washington-dc-d-c-riot/73-da19968c-b5ca-44d9-8e29-d1a80f06d66d |publisher=[[KUSA (TV)]] |title=Elected officials and others demand Reps. Boebert, Lamborn resign over Wednesday's Washington, D.C. riot |access-date=January 10, 2021 |date=January 7, 2021 |first=Marianne |last=Goodland |archive-date=January 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116190737/https://www.9news.com/article/news/politics/officials-boebert-lamborn-washington-dc-d-c-riot/73-da19968c-b5ca-44d9-8e29-d1a80f06d66d |url-status=live }}</ref> While the Capitol was being stormed, Boebert posted information on Twitter about the police response and the location of members, including that Speaker [[Nancy Pelosi]] had left the chamber; she has faced calls to resign for endangering members' safety.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Graziosi |first1=Graig |title=‘QAnon Congresswoman’ Lauren Boebert faces calls to resign after tweeting information about Nancy Pelosi during Capitol riot |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-election-2020/qanon-lauren-boebert-nancy-pelosi-capitol-riot-b1785663.html |website=Independent |access-date=January 16, 2021 |date=January 12, 2021 |archive-date=January 13, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210113213524/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-election-2020/qanon-lauren-boebert-nancy-pelosi-capitol-riot-b1785663.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Rogers |first1=Katie |title=A Republican Lawmaker for Whom the Spectacle Is the Point |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/13/us/politics/lauren-boebert-republican.html |website=The New York Times |access-date=January 16, 2021 |date=January 13, 2021 |archive-date=January 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210114202518/https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/13/us/politics/lauren-boebert-republican.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=QAnon congresswoman who live-tweeted Nancy Pelosi's location to rioters now facing calls for arrest |url=https://www.salon.com/2021/01/11/qanon-congresswoman-who-live-tweeted-nancy-pelosis-location-to-rioters-now-facing-calls-for-arrest_partner/ |website=Salon|first=David|last=Edwards |access-date=January 12, 2021 |language=en |date=January 11, 2021 |archive-date=January 12, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210112041421/https://www.salon.com/2021/01/11/qanon-congresswoman-who-live-tweeted-nancy-pelosis-location-to-rioters-now-facing-calls-for-arrest_partner/ |url-status=live }}</ref> On January 13, 2021, [[Twitter]] blocked Boebert's account until after January 20 because she had violated Twitter's rules.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Aedo|first=Zachary|date=January 13, 2021|title=Rep. Lauren Boebert says Twitter account locked until Inauguration Day|url=https://krdo.com/news/2021/01/13/lauren-boeberts-twitter-account-locked-until-inauguration-day/|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116190802/https://krdo.com/news/2021/01/13/lauren-boeberts-twitter-account-locked-until-inauguration-day/|archive-date=January 16, 2021|access-date=January 13, 2021|website=KRDO|language=en-US}}</ref> Hours later, Twitter unblocked Boebert's account, saying its staff "took the incorrect enforcement action."<ref name="Canales">{{cite news|last1=Canales|first1=Katie|date=January 13, 2021|title=Twitter says it has reversed its 'incorrect' decision to lock Rep. Lauren Boebert's account|work=Business Insider|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-locks-boebert-account-pelosi-capitol-siege-2021-1|url-status=live|access-date=January 14, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210113205645/https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-locks-boebert-account-pelosi-capitol-siege-2021-1|archive-date=January 13, 2021}}</ref>

Boebert's communications director resigned on January 16 in response to the events of January 6.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Markay|first=Lachlan|title=Communications director for gun-toting congresswoman quits|url=https://www.axios.com/boebert-communications-director-quits-f99c415e-dcf9-4507-a8d9-31c87280e39a.html|access-date=January 17, 2021|website=Axios|language=en}}</ref> Later that month, [[Parkland school shooting]] survivor and gun control activist [[David Hogg]] called Boebert and Representative [[Marjorie Taylor Greene]] "threats" to the Capitol. Boebert responded by calling Hogg a "child", adding, "We all saw how tough you were when questioned face to face", in an apparent reference to a 2019 incident in which Greene confronted Hogg about gun rights and called him a "coward."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Lonas |first1=Lexi |title=Boebert clashes with Parkland survivor on Twitter: 'Give your keyboard a rest, child' |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/news/536417-boebert-clashes-with-parkland-survivor-on-twitter-give-your-keyboard-a-rest |access-date=January 29, 2021 |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=January 28, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Wingerter |first1=Justin |title=U.S. Rep. Lauren Boebert feuds with Parkland shooting survivor David Hogg, angering Colorado Democrats |url=https://www.denverpost.com/2021/01/28/lauren-boebert-david-hogg-democrats/ |access-date=January 29, 2021 |work=[[The Denver Post]] |date=January 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210129091858/https://www.denverpost.com/2021/01/28/lauren-boebert-david-hogg-democrats/ |archive-date=January 29, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Quinn |first1=Allison |title=Rep. Lauren Boebert Mocks Parkland Survivor Over Marjorie Taylor Greene Video |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/rep-lauren-boebert-mocks-parkland-survivor-david-hogg-over-marjorie-taylor-greene-video |access-date=January 29, 2021 |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |date=January 28, 2021}}</ref> On January 19, 2021, [[San Francisco Giants]] owner [[Charles B. Johnson]] and his wife Ann Johnson asked Boebert to return their September 23, 2020, campaign contributions of $2,800 each.<ref>{{cite news |last=Pavlovic |first=Alex |url=https://www.nbcsports.com/bayarea/giants/giants-owner-charles-johnson-seeks-lauren-boebert-donation-refund |title=Giants owner Johnson seeks Boebert campaign donation refund |work=[[NBC Sports]] |date=January 19, 2021 |access-date=February 22, 2021}}</ref>

In 2010, Boebert's neighbors called police because they believed her [[pit bull]]s were threatening their dogs. Boebert received a ticket for dog code violations.<ref name="dp 20200827">{{Cite news |last=Wingerter |first=Justin |date=August 27, 2020 |title=Congressional candidate Lauren Boebert has a history of minor arrests, court no-shows |language=en-US |work=[[The Denver Post]] |url=https://www.denverpost.com/2020/08/27/lauren-boebert-arrests-colorado-3rd-mitsch-bush/ |access-date=October 7, 2020 |archive-date=January 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116190758/https://www.denverpost.com/2020/08/27/lauren-boebert-arrests-colorado-3rd-mitsch-bush/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

In 2015, she was cited for [[misdemeanor]] [[disorderly conduct]] at a music festival for telling officers that their arrest of a couple of [[Legal drinking age|underage drinkers]] was [[Constitutionality|unconstitutional]] because the teenagers had not received ''[[Miranda warning|Miranda]]'' warnings.<ref name="FMillerColoNewsL08132020">Miller, Faith. [https://coloradonewsline.com/2020/08/13/report-lauren-boebert-warned-arresting-deputies-she-had-friends-at-fox-news/ Report: Lauren Boebert warned arresting deputies she had 'friends at Fox News'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210106145422/https://coloradonewsline.com/2020/08/13/report-lauren-boebert-warned-arresting-deputies-she-had-friends-at-fox-news/ |date=January 6, 2021 }}, ''Colorado Newsline'', August 13, 2020. Retrieved January 4, 2021.  "The Mesa County district attorney's office dismissed a class 1 petty offense charge against Boebert "in the interest of justice," writing that there was "no reasonable likelihood of conviction should (the) case go to trial.""</ref> As she was being handcuffed, according to deputies' reports, Boebert tried to twist away from police, saying that "she had friends at [[Fox News]]" and that the arrest would be "national news".<ref name="FMillerColoNewsL08132020"/> She twice failed to appear in court on the charge.<ref name="FMillerColoNewsL08132020"/> The petty offense was dismissed because the [[Mesa County, Colorado|Mesa County]] [[district attorney]]'s office believed a jury would not convict her.<ref name="FMillerColoNewsL08132020"/>

In 2016, Boebert was cited for operating an unsafe vehicle; she pleaded guilty.<ref name="dp 20200827" /><ref>Hulse, Carl (September 26, 2010) [https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/26/us/colorado-lauren-boebert-congress.html "In Colorado, Fiery Political Novice Aims for a Seat in the House."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201003221814/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/26/us/colorado-lauren-boebert-congress.html |date=October 3, 2020 }} New York Times. (Retrieved October 7, 2020.)</ref>
